response:
[start of motion plan]
The task is to set the dislocated wrist back in place while grasping the wrist.

Understanding Robot-Applied Forces and Torques to Move Object in the Wrist Frame:
- Object Properties: The object is a human wrist with soft tissue and bones, estimated to have an effective mass around 2 kg for the manipulated volume. The wrist joint has some stiffness and limited mobility. Friction between the skin and gripper rubber pads is moderate with a static friction coefficient approximately 0.5. The wrist joint offers resistance to repositioning but allows smooth hinge-like rotational motion.
- Environmental Factors: Gravity acts downward (approximately along +Z in the world frame). The wrist rests partly on a table surface with friction around 0.6 static coefficient. The joint resistance includes some hinge torque resisting rotation out of place but not very high.
- Relevant object: The relevant object is a partially dislocated human wrist joint with soft tissue and bone, approximated mass 2 kg, and with a robot gripper, has a static friction coefficient of roughly 0.5.
- Surface of interaction is a skin-laden wrist surface and a lab table surface, mostly rigid with friction coefficient ~0.6 with the object.
- Contact Types: The robot maintains a pinch grasp securely on the dorsal side of the wrist using rubberized gripper pads, avoiding slipping while allowing pushing/pulling. The robot must maintain contact while applying rotational forces.
- Motion Type: The motion involves a combination of linear lifting and rotational torque to realign the wrist bones in the joint. The wrist must be lifted slightly (+Z) while rotated clockwise about the X-axis to reduce dislocation, then pushed laterally (+Y) to fully align. This includes controlled sliding, rotation, and lifting.
- Contact Considerations: Additional force along -X is required to maintain firm grip and prevent slipping; normal force to counter gravity must be sustained. Torques about X and Y axes must be carefully controlled to prevent excessive force causing pain or damage.
- Motion along axes: The robot exerts a combination of linear motion along +Z (lifting) and +Y (lateral push) axes while applying rotational torque clockwise about the X-axis and slight counterclockwise torque about the Y-axis to reposition the wrist.
- Task duration: To perform these motions carefully and safely, approximately 10 seconds will be required, allowing slow, controlled motion with feedback.

Physical Model:
- Relevant quantities and estimates: Mass = 2 kg, gravity force ~ 19.6 N downward, static friction coefficient (gripper-object) = 0.5, friction force capacity = grip normal force * 0.5; hinge torque resistance ~ 1 N-m.
- Relevant equations: Friction force = normal force x coefficient; torque = force x lever arm distance (approx. 0.05 m from wrist contact).
- Relevant assumptions: The wrist can be moved by applying ~5-10 N force linearly and ~1 N-m torque rotationally; robot can maintain grip force ~15 N safely.
- Computations: To overcome friction and gravity, vertical force > 20 N is needed; grasping normal force ~15 N provides sufficient friction; rotational torque required around X-axis ~1 N-m to reduce dislocation.
- Force/torque motion computations: The robot must apply force to lift (~20 N counteracting gravity and friction), push laterally (~10 N overcoming joint resistance), and apply torque (~1 N-m) to rotate wrist into alignment.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis: To complete the task and based upon the need to maintain grip and counteract slipping, the robot must exert negative force along the X-axis with magnitude 10 N on the object in the image.
Linear Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon the lateral pushing required to reposition the wrist bones, the robot must exert positive force along the Y-axis with magnitude 10 N on the object in the image.
Linear Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon the need to lift the wrist against gravity and friction, the robot must exert positive force along the Z-axis with magnitude 20 N on the object in the image.
Angular X-axis: To complete the task and based upon the resistance of dislocation and motion required to realign joint, the robot must exert angular clockwise torque about the X-axis with magnitude 1.0 N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon small realigning rotational motion required, the robot must exert angular counterclockwise torque about the Y-axis with magnitude 0.3 N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Z-axis: No torque is required about the Z-axis as no twisting rotation is necessary.
Grasping force: The estimated force range must overcome slipping and provide stabilization during lifting and repositioning; thus grasping force should be 15 to 20 N.

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "Human wrist joint with soft tissue and bones, approx. 2 kg mass, skin-rubber gripper friction coefficient 0.5, joint hinge resisting with ~1 N-m torque, table surface friction ~0.6"
# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Lift wrist along +Z, push laterally along +Y, maintain grip force along -X, apply clockwise torque about X to realign joint, slight counterclockwise torque about Y for fine adjustment."
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [-10, 10, 20, 1.0, -0.3, 0]
# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 17
# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 10
```

[end of motion plan]
message:
Given the user instruction and an image of the robot workspace, generate a structured physical plan for a robot end-effector interacting with the environment.
The task is to set the dislocated wrist back in place while grasping the wrist.

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.
Use physical reasoning to complete the following plan in a structured format. Carefully map the required motion in the world to the required motion, forces, and torques at the wrist.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
